posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53236225
If >>53236096 really is what Google Lens output reading that page, it's not that great at all. It has trouble grabbing context from surrounding panels and apparently even tracking across speech bubbles in the same panel.
It also doesn't help that in Meows' first speech bubble she trails off her sentence, which happens a lot more in Japanese than it does in English (You're literally expected to fill in the blank even though it could technically be any number of things). In this instance, she's probably going for "I hate Master now..." but upon hearing her trainer offer to actually take her on a date, she abruptly changes the "hate" (which would have been at the end) to "super-duper love".
It's not Lens's fault, it's just nowhere near sophisticated enough to be able to figure that out. It's dealing with information so obscure and unspoken that you have to almost pull it out of thin air, which humans are great at, but robots just don't have a clue yet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53243840
Honestly the more I'm pondering this, the weirder it is to think about. Ruby/Sapphire would end effectively cutting out a large number of pokemon, since without FRLG or the Gamecube games there's no way to get large swathes of Kanto or Johto mons.

DP does bring back quite a few, even if they are postgame only, which I think would set a trend going forward in this alternate timeline. There is the other weird issue where you wouldn't be able to get certain cross-gen evos at all due to not being able to catch say, Magby without Leafgreen existing, and therefore Magmortar just doesn't exist without hacking. I'd assume in such a timeline Gamefreak may have stuck them into the game in some other way, but strictly speaking they don't exist.
Black/White then does a mix, where it features a lot of brand new pokemon, being a soft reboot similar to R/S, but it also brings back some other old pokemon for the first time in the postgame.

XY I could see actually being extremely popular purely for the fact that it would be the first return of a lot of Gen 1 mons like the Starters or Legendary Birds in over a decade, and on top of that, they'd largely be available before beating the game, since Kalos started the trend of very large regional Dex sizes, and in a timeline where the regional dex is 90% of the pokemon in a game, that matters a lot. Add the Friend Safari on top of that and there's even more in the postgame.
Combine that with the fact that XY never had a third version and it ends up looking very good in this timeline, at least relative to every other Gen which is now made worse.

I'm not sure if the reception to SWSH or SV would be that drastically different. Overall I think modern games would be seen in a more favorable light though, since there wouldn't be Platinum/Emerald or HGSS that people often like to point to as the peak of pokemon.
Another factor would be what Gamefreak spends the extra development time on instead, but that's another can of worms.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53245519
It’s AR geocaching. There are two teams.

You go to a specific coordinate, “hack the portal” (basically spinning a pokestop), and get some attack/defense items and a “key”.

-Use the defense items to power up a portal.
-Use attack items to damage opposing portals and take them over.
-Use keys to link two portals with a line. Lines can’t cross other lines.

When you form a triangle using the links, you capture the area enclosed by the triangle. Ingress nerds love to make huge obnoxious triangles because you also can’t make lines under captured areas

Happy Valentine's Day! Still working on True Love Never Fades. Slow going but I hope this Friday's episode motivates me. Wrote something for y'all that I'll post in 3 parts throughout the day. :3

Pokemon Master ~ Day 51

The sun shimmered through a tiny hole in the otherwise overcast afternoon sky, appropriately painting the tops of numerous skyscrapers a lacquered golden.

This was only Latias' second week in Goldenrod City, and her first time being anywhere other than Alto Mare. Sure, she had ridden the updrafts high above various areas of Johto before, but had never touched down nor had reason to until the past ten days she'd spent shacked up with Ash.

The sky darkened considerably as the smoky gray, nearly charcoal black clouds sealed the hole the sun had snuck its rays through. A small swarm of Murkrow noisily squabbled overhead, causing the disguised dragon debutante to look up and watch them fly toward their nests early that day. She caught sight of one large building with a giant mechanical Castform on top. It began to glow blue and shift its pistons and parts into a semblance of one in rainy form just as she began to feel raindrops lightly pelting her arms and neck.

While Latias still didn't quite understand the reasoning behind how humans lived, she admired their technological ingenuity nonetheless. Her reflected image of a human hand clutched an umbrella more tightly to her side as she hurried along.

To better understand human ways for Ash, she had spent much of her time in Goldenrod reading about culture at a place called a library. There she had learned about the romantic concept of "aiaigasa" and was eager to show up for Ash at his "interview building" with the umbrella when he wasn't expecting her.

On her way, she passed another familiar building with a large display window that had caught her attention and caused her to linger for much of the past week. She was dismayed to find the object shown off behind the glass now missing.

Pokemon Master ~ Day 51

Ash was absolutely ecstatic as he practically ran through the lobby of the Sukoyaka corporate building in Goldenrod City. After a rigorous 10 day interview process, he was given the job of traveling to the most remote places on the planet to research Pokemon in an official capacity. Despite similar experiences way back when he was 10, this time he'd be paid and his work would be published in peer reviewed journals of the likes that Professor Oak revered.

Ash noticed the unusual darkness looming and was met with a light steady rain once outside. It didn't stop him from taking a jumping leap into the air and whooping out in joy, not caring who would see him.

Just when he started worrying about how he'd get back to his hotel in Azalea Town without being completely drenched, he noticed a familiar girl with sparkling eyes and a big smile leaning against a post and holding an umbrella. Ash grinned, rushing over to her and giving her a big hug. She wrapped the arm not holding an umbrella around him.

Latias no longer took the form of Bianca and had instead chosen a new form with features seemingly plucked out of Ash's brain as being most attractive. Truth be told, he preferred being with her in her true form. It felt unique, special, and she was just the most radiant and ravishing that way. But that was best enjoyed in private.

"I got it! I got the job!" Ash shouted excitedly to his sweetheart. A slight worried look flashed over Latias' features, but was quickly replaced by an open mouth exclamation of glee, and a very unnhumanlike nuzzle of her head into Ash's chest.

The birdplane leaned her head on Ash's shoulder as they shared the umbrella and traveled down Route 34, the other people out and about smiling at their closeness. Loud sheets of rain now pelted the umbrella as they disappeared into Ilex Forest.

Pokemon Master ~ Day 51

Upon entering the forest, numerous Caterpie and Oddish could be seen scrambling and taking cover inside trees and beneath bushes. The collected rain falling from the canopy, along with the strange violent gusts of wind made the storm even more perilous within the forest.

One such gust pried the umbrella from Latias' hand and before she could react, smashed it against a tree and broke it in three places. "LAAA!" She yelped despite still appearing as human before reverting back to true form anyway since no other humans were in the forest with them. She quickly used her psychic energy to direct any rain around them away, creating a transparent orb of dryness around them.

Ash looked into Latias' golden eyes. They looked sad and practically close to tears. Her little ear wings also appeared to be drooping. It was as if something involving the umbrella had been very important to her.

The human lifted the dragon's chin until she was looking directly into his eyes. "Hey, don't worry about it. Look, I got you something."

Latias watched as Ash pulled something from his pocket that caused all the sadness to melt from her eyes. It was a small golden likeness of a Latias clutching the shape of a heart, connected to a chain.

"It's a locket. I saw you looking at it in the department store window in Goldenrod every day." Ash said as he flipped it open to reveal small pictures of them he'd already put in.

Latias tackled him to the ground, vocalizing loudly and rubbing her neck all over him as he chuckled and stroked her. "I guess you like it, huh?"

She responded by manipulating the rain she was deflecting into a shimmery see-through clone of herself and inviting it into the dryness orb with them. Ash chuckled as he suddenly had two Latias nuzzling and kissing him, one on each side. One was very cold and clammy, but didn't soak him somehow.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53246322
Apart from mostly different tile sets (roofs, signs, buildings, paths, fences, etc.), Cerulean Cave's layout is different between RG, Blue, and Yellow. FRLG follows the RG design. There's no difference in other layouts. In terms of other game differences, Blue has a mix of RG's encounters. For example, RG have several pairs that aren't version-exclusives, but are more common in one version over the other.
>Caterpie/Metapod & Weedle/Kakuna
>Nidoran-F/Nidorina & Nidoran-M/Nidorino
>Psyduck/Golduck & Slowpoke/Slowbro
>Grimer/Muk & Koffing/Weezing
>Shellder & Staryu

In addition to having a mix of the actual exclusives
>Ekans/Arbok & Sandshrew/Sandslash
>Vulpix/Ninetales & Growlithe/Arcanine
>Oddish/Gloom/Vileplume & Bellsprout/Weepinbell/Victreebel
>Meowth/Persian & Mankey/Primeape
>Electibuzz & Magmar
>Scyther & Pinsir
Though neither Electibuzz or Magmar are available, and instead Jynx can be found in the wild in the Seafoam Islands. And you can also find Ditto in the Rock Tunnel. The in-game trades are different, the Game Corner prizes are altered, all Pokémon sprites are new, the player sprite is updated, there are various bug fixes, etc. No changes to movesets or Trainers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53228733
More like there was more shit they wanted to include in and around each major area, but were unable to due to technical constraints. They had to choose between either doing all of Japan but extremely watered down (like what they did with all of Kanto in the beta map), or trim it down to just Johto and Kanto and use the cartridge space to flesh it out better. because of this, they ultimately decided to give Hoenn and Sinnoh their own games under the same design philosophy - keep it restricted to a specific region instead of trying to cover everything at once, and focus instead on making it feel more like an actual place and less like walking on a road map with only a few select locations. It looks like they dropped that idea with X and Y, though - we got all of France crammed into a single map instead of focusing on fleshing out a few of the individual provinces; same thing with Galar/Great Britain, and Paldea/Spain (though Alola/Hawaii was understandable).

Originally, Gold/Silver was going to be the last game, and they'd make it even if Red/Green flopped. >>53230286
Maybe? I know that the path to the Gigaleak has been closed, but it's unclear to me if the leaker and pals actually gave us everything. I understood it as they had more than what they shared so there might be stuff out there. But I feel like there's also not as much determined interest in getting access to that information. People wanted to see RBY / GSC because it was so early in the franchise and we had so many hints and teasers of what we had missed out on, plus it has the magic of being such an early time of the franchise that it's almost alien by today's standards. I personally would love to see RSE because it was such a big jump for Pokémon and I think people are sleeping on the potential of what they might actually have in the beta content there. But I don't think people are really going to dig for it. And I feel like with BW we might know most things? They did a pretty extensive explanation of where all the Pokémon came from and the development of that game, Dr Lava did a lot of the translation there. So I don't know what mysteries we really have other than maybe seeing some of the earlier designs for real or knowing how they landed on making Unova itself. I'm all for it though

This romhack is a mixture of the assets, known informations of the development builds of the game and made up stuff which i will explain what it is
>various betamons which frontsprites are the made up ones and the backsprites are the ones that were the leaked material
>while Agatha has her Beta team, some trainers have teams which are not listed in any development builds like Jack with Omega (Omega was supposed to be a legendary) were given one like Yujiro and Silph Co. Chief or left unchanged like Giovanni first team
>a pre-gym in Viridian City was added with Yujiro (called Eric) as the Leader, originally was the Leader of Viridian City before replaced with Giovanni
>gym guide originally looked like the coach from Rocky Joe
>safari zone has a Silph Co. Chief as the boss, his appearance would be later given to Blaine with the original chief being scrapped
>moltres has it's own dungeon which is Cerulean Cave without restrictions as only Surf was needed to enter, during development Mewtwo was found in the Silph Co. (said building was supposed to final area of the game during development), Moltres was moved in the Victory Road
>robot jack was added in the Silph Co. (being taken over in the romhack) which originally was there but scrapped, likely because would have given the impression Silph was manifacturing them since Rocket on it's own can't
>blaine gym was not changed to his beta one but Blaine himself was
>fuchsia city has a room all about Mewtwo

I appreciate that you're actually trying to start a conversation. And I love it. I think that, in my ideal world, it would have still been the GSC that we got but there would have been some modern style integration of the betamons back into the fold either in Crystal or something like Stadium 2. Not all of them, but the more interesting ones. I would have loved to see whatever that original canine legendary was as well as the tigers, wolfman and a few others. Some of those designs are actually really cool and I think they would have completely changed the trajectory of the franchise. Maybe I'll get some disagreement and even hate for saying this, but I remember when RS came out and the dex was leaking because I'm that fucking old. A lot of those Pokémon did not look like Pokémon and I remember at the time the internet community was sort of divided on whether they were really cool or the series had jumped the shark. And I wonder if they stuck to their guns with the beta Pokémon from GSC if that would not have happened. A lot of those designs definitely had more of a goofy, generic RPG monster and sort of fun feel to them. But once Generation 3 came out, we started seeing more Pokémon that were directly inspired by a specific animal/mythology and a lot more Pokémon who were monstrous or "complex." And we never really went totally back

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53214932
The series really would have gone in a different direction of this was closer to the end product. So many of these beta designs fall into the "goofy" territory and look like any generic anime/JRPG Monster, like all of the bunny looking things, the scarecrow bird, or several of the babies. Then you get random tough looking monsters like the scorpion or Viking boat, which seem honestly out of place next to everything else. And we also have what appears to be a line with four stages with that dryad looking Pokemon. Ultimately I'm ok with what we really got bc it had a more healthy mix that leaned into having monsters that looked more tough and I think it helped develop more of that essence that modern Pokémon have, which sets them apart from the other '90s JRPGs. But if we continued down the path of the beta seems to be taking us, I think the series would have become much different and probably have more of a DQ Monsters or Demikids feel than how it is today.

I think I've said this before, but I'll reiterate. I think generation 3 is actually the holy grail that nobody has talking about. Seeing more content for the first few generations is obviously extremely cool and I want it. But generation 3 was such a huge jump in every facet. I really want to know what they were thinking and going through when developing that game. The design process for how the Pokémon looked and functioned was different, the mechanics were different, they tried to meet the world feel more alive with a grander scale and scope... It's also very clear that they may have played with the type chart and what exactly abilities were going to be. I remember back in the day hearing rumors that some of the Pokémon in the early demos did not have the same types that we have now, and there's stuff in the code suggesting that some Pokémon were actually going to have no abilities. I really want to know what that version of the game looked like. Because it seems to me like they may have actually wanted to add another type or at the very least have abilities function as sort of unique characteristics that not everybody got

>>53232770
I think that's the unfortunate reality with RSE. They were at a point where they knew what Pokémon was and how they wanted to change it, so everything was pretty much documented instead of just bullshitted. I get the impression that the first two generations were very similar to how the original Mega Man games on the NES were created -- everyone on the development team just kind of shot ideas into the dark and everybody voted on their favorites, refining each other's concepts until they got something they all agreed upon as pretty cool. Whereas I think RSE sort of began the idea that the Pokémon were going to be created by a select few members of the team who were like the experts and then everybody else had specific jobs. This is all speculation, I don't know for a fact. But it seems like in all the generations going forward there are a few people that design the Pokémon and have that creative input, and then there's also the TPCI input that probably deletes Pokémon they don't like as well. The first two generations did not have that

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53232706
It's still bizarre to me how Generation 3 is now over 20 years old and people still haven't unearthed some sort of holy grail of all of that concept art. People forget that there were a handful of Generation 3 Pokémon who were appearing during Generation 2's time, and similar to how GSC Pokémon popped up during the RBY cycle we had slow reveals and integration of RSE Pokémon into the GSC cycle. That game was in development for a pretty long time, so there definitely had to be a lot of scraps that were saved somewhere. Generation 4 and 5 would also have this, maybe 6. But that's definitely something we don't get anymore with the super fast development cycle they've created for themselves. Now we get Pokémon revealed an instantly can play as them within the year, whereas I distinctly recall being in middle school/high school knowing that at some point in the future, I didn't know when, I would be using something like Kecleon or Blaziken And there was a ton of speculation for all that time. I kind of miss it. But I also like I said want to see what the fuck they had cooking behind the scenes because RSE definitely changed a lot of things and we know they had ideas that they threw out

>>53232706
something about RSE that i find interesting are the early dex entries. people never really talk about them, but theres details about pokemon that were evidently changed throughout development, plus actual dex extries describing entirely scrapped pokemon. reminds of how back sprites are all we have of gen 1 beta mons, except now theres even less to go off of
https://tcrf.net/Development:Pok%C3%A9mon_Ruby_and_Sapphire/Pok%C3%A9mon_Data

some random ones i find interesting:

>Category: Foster, Normal
>"If it has no offspring, it will seek out a small living thing and place it onto its back. It brushes its teeth by gnawing on hard objects."
>"A Pokémon that wraps its tail around to make a cradle while raising its child on its back. Sometimes it bonds with a different creature."
">It can run 50 meters in 7 seconds flat. Sometimes, it may accidentally drop its child."
Definitely not Maushold but it really sounds like it in a lot of ways

>Category: Shrub, Grass/Water
">It collects a large amount of water inside its body and sprays it out like a shower while rotating. It is convenient to have around on hot summer days."
>"It drinks over 100 liters of water a day. When the water it has collected in its body gets low, the leaves on both its hands wither."
This dex entry is pretty much describing Water Sport's animation, which was a move added in gen 3. I'm pretty certain this mon and the move were designed for each other, much like the voodoo doll mon and Curse

>Category: Sightseeing, Flying
>"A Pokémon that loves to fly with a human riding it. It quietly flies and is completely comfortable to ride. When it tires, it rests with its wings floating atop the sea."
>"Has a calm personality, so it dislikes fighting. Its horn(s) have magnet-like cells that act as a compass."
Maybe coincidence but I can't help but think of >>53232706

>>53243290
Pikachu can hit pretty hard with the Light Ball but it's still a shitmon.
Lapras and Blastoise are trouble because the hail during this fight makes Blizzard have 100% accuracy, but your electric type should still be able to bring them down.
Venusaur and Charizard aren't too dangerous either.
Snorlax is a bulky fucker, also has Blizzard, but at least it's not the gen 2 version of the fight where Snorlax was the strongest non-legendary pokemon in the game and had Rest to heal. A good Fighting type can stop him.
Lead with a Ground type like Donphan or Sandslash and Earthquake the rat. Have some other good mons. Generic HGSS mons like Ampharos and Espeon can handle themselves fine. Meganium unfortunately falls off during the endgame but it can still put up screens. Tyranitar can also remove Hail on top of being very powerful in general.

>>53235038
Actually, I reflected on this a bit more and I think the reason I'm interested in this kind of artwork is because it triggers feeling of empathy. The desire to protecc, to save, to hug. Like, you see someone at their lowest and you can't help but empathize because you probably been there or been close enough to know or understand how it feels. Obviously, there is natural desire to [fantasize about] save them, to make thing better for them.
It is an artificial forced trigger, sure, but it works, it gets you the feels you need and that's enough.

Incorrect. Although Vaporeon often jokingly called a fish, it isnt one, it isnt even an amphibian. It is semi-aquatic like seals or otters, for example. They dont have gills because they have classic lungs.

>>53238272
People think that their pets act like children, and some even treat them like children. Google things like "pets childlike" or "dogs childlike" and you'll see actual studies done connecting dog's and cat's behaviors to that of children. Of course pets aren't in any way children but people notice certain innocent qualities they may share. This is the innocent part Tajiri was alluding to in his biography.

But I think the crucial detail people here miss is the construction of Pokémon. Pokémon may behave child-like, or innocent, but that doesn't make them as children. You don't keep kids in glorified pet carriers, breed them and trade away their offspring, keep them in farms out in the open like cattle, or treat them the same way one does their dog. Pokémon aren't people, they're dependent on their owners, they're subordinate to their owners and they lack personhood. Their construction mirrors that of real pets which isn't surprising given their creator compared them to cats and dogs. This construction is how you can get people to see Gengar abandonment as like one abandoning a dog despite Gengar apperance. In the YouTube video people are comparing Gengar situation to an abandoned pet or a misunderstood animal. On reddit people even called the whole situation the "jurassic bark" of Pokémon which involved a dog waiting for his owner to the point of death, something we have seen in Pokémon.

Yesterday someone said Pokémon are like yokai which isn't true. Not only because we have actual written sources stating the opposite but also because of the conceptualization of Pokémon in the mold of pets and critters. Pokémon may be magical but in-universe they're contextualized as natural creatures, their powers and they don't fall under the supernatural category. This is best seen with ghost type Pokémon not being ghosts, supernatural entities, but living creatures with ghost-like properties, which in this context makes them natural creatures.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53240932
Pets in fiction do all the things you mentioned. Watch cartoons, video games or even shows grounded in reality. Lassie the dog could perform feats no ordinary dog could do but this wasn't treated as exceptional. Snoopy could write a novel and day dream about being a ww1 ace pilot, and Peanuts is based off Schultz's childhood and snoopy off his own childhood pet. I can come up with numerous examples but the point is that none of it is strange in fiction. All those pets have these abilities but they're still conceptualized as pets, Snoopy may be more intelligent than Charlie Brown but he's still Charlie's pet dog and does pet things. Much the same Pokémon may be fantastical but they're conceptualized as pets that do pet things like chew on shoes.

Tajiri was also adamant on this and he makes it clear in his 2018 biography but also back in 1995 where he describes Pokémon as "kaiju-like pets" in a book he wrote. Red and Blue has Oak explicitly stating Pokémon are kept as pets and Tajiri even imagines Pokémon battles as two dog owners going on a walk.

The allure of Pokémon is their fantastical, cute nature combined with the familiarity of critters and pets, which all these statements have explicit confirmation from the people who work on the series. There's a big reason people think of Pokémon the way they do.

>>53241647
Pokemon as a concept are bound to that. The points that I want to get across are the way the series goes about it and by showcasing it's deliberate by showing word from the people who run, worked on and even created the series.

Those post are a manifestation of all that work. The whole point is that people pick up on context clues even when the subject are fantasy creatures. Being able to talk or what have you doesn't detract from that, and the Pokémon series is very conservative on that front anyways. This is why I brought up other examples like Snoopy being able to read and write, create a novel and things like that, it doesn't detract that Snoopy is still a dog and Charlie Brown's pet dog at that. Yogi isn't anyone's pet but a bear that lives in a forest reserve. His cave may be styled after a modern home but it's still a cave, he lives in the forest and the series presents him as a bear.

With Pokémon the series is very unsubtle about it, they beat you with that fact everytime you interact with your Pokémon and the anime does the same too. This are the things that shape the perception people have over Pokémon. And The Pokémon Company has done a great job at this based off the arguments that occur here, comments shown in other websites and how people in general see Pokémon. The Viz video with the comments has over a million views with plenty of people making the pet/critter comparison.

In the end Pokémon is unapologetic over this subject. This is why it's important to note the things the series does, including the rejection of the supernatural for Pokémon and even the label monster. Early product guides were telling 3rd parties not to refer to Pokémon as monsters, and Shudo very rarely uses the terms, instead writing that the anime staff decided to think of Pokémon in *animal* terms, never as monsters. In Scarlet and Violet there's a rejection of Pokémon as monsters as part of the main story too. It's all a peculiar construction.

posts.com:
>>53242043
Bug is pretty bad offensively, yes.

Dark is a really good target to hit, but Fighting generally does better. And Psychic's fallen off quite a bit unfortunately, and again, Ghost and Dark do that job way better. So it's not an outwardly necessary trait to have. But the worst part is, just how many god damn things resist it. Fairy, Fire, Flying, Steel, Poison, Ghost and Fighting. That's a metric fuck ton, and to make matters worse, theyre ALL common types (except maybe Poison, but even so its relevant enough). It's fucking ridiculous.


On the other hand, Bug is actually decent defensively. Being resistant to both Ground and Fighting is a really nice trait, and it pairs well with a lot of other types, most notably Steel.

You know what I feel like adding to this because it's just stupid. Using Boomburst as an example is just being dishonest. Boomburst could be almost any type and people would take it because it's a move with 140 base power that hits through subs. Boomburst has to be that broken to be considered worth taking. Meanwhile, moves that are middling but have no downsides like Flamethrower, Thunderbolt, or Ice Beam are worth considering despite being way weaker than Boomburst. Normal isn't great offensively, because it needs a move that would be broken on any other type to be "good".

It's kind of interesting looking back at earlier gens and seeing how the three main types were differentiated. Fire being very wide in its offensive and defensive prowess with water having a slightly narrower scope with both types having roughly equivalent BP in their moves. posts.com: Here’s a leak just so you guys don’t get your hopes up. Pokémon Together is like Pokémon Home for the first 3 generations. This is so you can have a GTS / online simulation without having their updated stats, moves, typings, etc. Gens 1-3 are coming to NSO over the next 3 quarters of this year, with Together compatibility. Together can transfer into Home, meaning you can legitimately go from Gen 1 to Gen 9 for the first time, on one system. Together also has an online Gen 3 battle simulator, that is Chunsoft’s involvement. The only mystery dungeon announcement you should expect any time soon is Red Rescue Team on NSO.

>>53245528
Dog tail is just moving it left and right until it bends at around a quarter circle. Equally so up and down. Cat tail is the same but it bends even more, and the opposite happens with big heavy tails. I'd imagine it feels awkward when trying to combine both motions to draw a full circle in the air.

When it comes to it being voluntary or involuntary, I assume it's like expressing emotions with your face. Where you don't have complete control over your facial features at all times, but it's not like moving them is a totally subconscious act. You could suppress a tail wag the same way one may want to keep a poker face in spite of feeling strong emotions.

I suppose it also would feel like an limb would when it comes to the sense of touch. Prehensile tails are anyone's guess. Yes I've autistically thought about this question an unhealthy amount.

>Ralts Convergent Line
>Ralts: Dark/Fairy, resembles a little banshee with tattered robes and messy hair. It's always sad and crying, even when happy. Any moment where it's quiet is its trainer's only reprieve.
>Kirlia: Dark/Fairy. Still looking a little messy, but wearing a nicer outfit and has its hair set up like a gothic doll. Keeps the dark theme from Ralts, but is more calm. Easily capable of going berserk, it tries to hold in its cries to not inconvenience its trainer.

Here's a few I'm coming up with kind of kind of on the spot

>Miteor
>Minior convergent, pure Bug type
>The rocky shell is actually a carapace and when it cracks a very bizarre looking soft bodied bug is inside. It's extremely lightweight which is why it floats on the wind. May also have the same ability as Minior, but maybe not

>Cotta
>Ditto converegent, pure Ground type
>A mud man concept, it's a chunk of malleable natural clay that looks similar to Ditto. Instead of transforming, it has a normal moveset but its gimmick is that because it is so malleable it learns a lot of unconventional moves because it can reform its body into somewhat crude shapes and designs (while not actually being able to completely mimic another Pokémon like Ditto can). Also has a schtick about being able to break off pieces of itself that form into miniature versions of itself, which may play into a signature ability. But I also like the idea of it actually having an altered variant of or the actual Imposter ability as its HA too.

>Zatso and Clobboffet
>Pure Fighting convergent for the Wobba line
>Actual training dummy type creatures that looks similar to the other Pokémon line, but are actually very tough monsters who have become used to using their strong hide and defense as the ultimate offense.

>Tynado, Eelicane and Eelirecho
>Flying/Ghost convergent forms for the Tynamo line
>They are basically those Japanese flying rods that have become similar to the original line, though the latter two stages look further and further away and become more spectral and bizarre. Because of their flying type they do not have levitate, but I think it would be interesting if they had volt absorb or something similar instead to call back to the originals having electric typing with levitate

Post headcanons (>inb4 fanfic) of the Pokémon world that you think make sense or you just thought of on a whim.

Questions from >>53171300 continued for freebies.
>How hard would it be to catch Route 1 mons? Cave, water, forest encounters? Pseudos assuming you can find them?
>Would (you) find a Pokémon useful in your current job?
>Do all Pokémon speak the same language? To what extent can they communicate with humans?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>How hard would it be to catch Route 1 mons? Cave, water, forest encounters? Pseudos assuming you can find them?
(assuming you mean in general and not based off of Pokémon that'd live where I live or something) Route 1 would be piss easy. Literally just set out some food for a Rattata or some shit and bam, you have your mon. Rock types in caves would probably also be about as easy as picking them up and not harming them (the bats would be way harder for obvious reasons), Pseudos would probably bite your hand off before you could even try, etc. The games give a pretty good estimation of how easy it is to catch any given thing with catch rates; pretty sure they're not meant to be literal representations of how good the ball is, but instead catch-alls to signify the difficulty level of what you're attempting to catch.
>Would (you) find a Pokémon useful in your current job?
I'm still studying but trying to get something at minimum wage to support myself. I think a Pokémon would be more useful for studying than any job I could get at the moment. Then again, just having *someone* there for me would help, so maybe that doesn't count...
>Do all Pokémon speak the same language? To what extent can they communicate with humans?
I go along with pic rel as a headcanon because I think it makes sense considering Mew and it keeps a bit of mystique around the Pokémon instead of just making them "literally animals with superpowers".
>How do trainer battles handle the concept of the victor being awarded cash? How does it affect the economy?
It's probably just common courtesy. I like to think it started as a dare amongst kids and just stuck around when those kids grew up. It's probably not set in stone as a law or anything.
>Any region you'd settle down in? Which town?
Hoenn, probably in Lilycove. The Safari Zone is fun, the city looks gorgeous, contests are right there if you want them. I think it's just situated and built very nicely in an already-nice region.

For sure, it makes sense to limit the availability of something that shifts battles so heavily in your favor.
--------------
On a separate note regarding badges, thought of a rough outline during my morning commute, hopefully other anons can expand on it.
>First gym, tests basic type matchups, not unheard of for trainers to travel just so their first gym is a favorable matchup
>Second gym, knowledge of status and berries, first time challengers are given a handful of freebies, and when berries ripen in just a few days I'm sure they're not too expensive
>Third gym, pivoting, gym leaders Pokémon carry some sort of coverage, stresses importance of not over relying on one team member, gym leader can also switch out when favorable.
>Fourth gym, held items, can be anything from "in a pinch" berries, to Eviolite, Focus Sash, nothing like Choice items or Life Orb
>Fifth gym, some aspects of previous gyms, namely held items and pivoting, introduces entry hazards, stat boosts. Trainers have access to Taunt by purchase at this point, should be noted.
>Sixth gym, weather effects, how it affects certain types, and abilities that take advantage of it. Type of weather depends on the gym leader.
>7th and 8th gym leaders can be doubles, use support moves, status, pivots are now U-Turn/Baton Pass/Volt Switch, tests you on how well you can apply previous gym strategies to your own teams advantage.

>How influential are regions Leagues? Are some more powerful than others? Alliances, rivalries, maintaining the balance of power?
Considering the general state of peace in the world, I think that it's more of a modern-day situation where the entire world is built on multiple alliances and a mutual agreement not to blow each other to high hell if someone gets mad. Especially since each champion essentially has friendly nukes anyways (especially in regions like Kalos and Galar), I'm guessing there are hundreds of checks and balances to prevent stuff like the old Kalosian War from ever happening again in the present day. Every Champion probably swears an oath to do no harm and focuses more on regional affairs than foreign incidents, especially with Interpol about to handle that instead.
Neighbors probably influence each other somewhat. Johto and Kanto are known to share a league, which means they're definitely intertwined at the very minimum. It's also been noted that Unova is the capital of movie-making with Kalos supplying its biggest stars, so I think if there's any influence from other regions it usually comes in the form of entertainment- either in the form of movies or championship tournaments broadcast on TV. I doubt most regions are affected much by others' foreign policies.
In my head, in terms of power, Unova has always ranked pretty high due to the high evolution levels and the billions of battle facilities (PWT, White Tree Hollow, Black City, Battle Subway, etc), with Galar and Sinnoh coming soon after for similar reasons (though Galar is mostly just there due to the Masters 8 and Dynamax). Kalos and the tropical regions probably take things pretty slow, while Johto is weaker than Kanto but still probably stronger than Kalos or Alola (even if it's the weakest of the Japanese regions in my head). Paldea is definitely in the middle of the bell curve, it just seems like it should be there. Weaker than Hoenn, stronger than Kalos/Alola/Johto/etc.

>So early trainer obviously have it easy with the Route 1 mons, but how dedicated do they have to be to evolve their partner? Do many reach a wall with middle stage evos if the line has three stages? Open ended, mention other evolution scenarios like stones or friendship if you wish.
In my mind it depends on the pokemon species. Something like a rattata or patrat would be easier to evolve. It's the same for bug pokemon since it's been said that they're easier to evolve. For stage 3 mons I feel like it would take a much longer time, something like several years. Stone evolutions would require the item but also a lot of trust between the pokemon and the trainer. I also feel like it depends on how many pokemon a trainer has. The less pokemon a trainer has the more time can be focused on training that pokemon which means it would evolve sooner.
>>Would any old trainer with a Pokemon be allowed to use a Pokecenter free of charge?
Does it more closely resemble modern insurance where those without a Pokedex have copays for healing their team or is it truly free healthcare?
I live in Canada so I just assumed it worked similar to here. It's free, technically, but we pay through taxes. Medications wouldn't be covered though, but depending on your insurance it could be partly covered.
>How did different regions, champions, trainers, react to the discovery of Fairy types?
There probably was some criticism and arguments just like with anything that is ground breaking in science. I feel like the media would have a field day. Eventually it would be normalized and people would move on.
>How influential are regions Leagues? Are some more powerful than others? Alliances, rivalries, maintaining the balance of power?
It depends on the region. In Paldea it seems pretty influential since it's directly tied to the education system. Maybe once a year they would have an poke-olympics where every country competes.
I hope these threads become a regular thing, I really enjoy them.

/vpwt/ - Reality vs Expectation edition
>post fanfics you like
>share your own fics, ask for advice, post story updates
>discuss writerly struggles with fellow writefriends

Previous Thread: >>53154813

Check out the catalog for a directory of fics from fellow writefags: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1PtN4D_9CSw8JJ9uO6v0oQqdtKEkS8aFAvfxqI96XfSE
Gallery of art drawn for stories in the thread: https://imgur.com/a/sjdck

>Can I post NSFW fics?
There are no rules against NSFW text links.

>How should I post my fics?
If it's short enough to fit into a couple of posts, posting to the thread is fine. If you want to share longer works, or if you want more permanent storage, you can link to a host: fanfiction.net, AO3, Pastebin, or Google Docs.

>I'm not a writer but I want to contribute
Feel free to give stories posted a read and critique as you see fit. Keep it relevent to the story.
>Can I request something?
You're encouraged to post prompts, i.e. short snippets or greentext sequences describing your ideas. You can also expand on prompts posted by others. If writing an entire story from start to finish feels too daunting, this is a way to get started.

>I have this idea about [event/technology/...]
Feel free to post your thoughts about how specific parts of the Pokémon world function as well. Worldbuilding is always welcome.

>Can I add a fic I wrote to the catalog?
Check the catalog for the submission link. Fill out the form with all the necessary information and it will be submitted for review automatically.

We're also looking to collect ideas for fanfics as a resource for stumped writers. Feel free to throw an idea out there; someone may choose to use it themselves!
Ideabin: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1X072SSWulcC6RJRrPA6v9XtyohRybvMBl6Fh49wHsRw

>>53216627
Pokemon are vehicles for human conflict. They're never the focus of the plot, they're the gimmick of the setting. Like magic in the HP universe. The games, the show, whatever, they all focus on the human characters and their struggles, because that's what the audience really wants to see., pokemon are little more than animals in canon.

There's nothing *wrong* with exclusively focusing on people, and you shouldn't think otherwise unless you're a furfag writing PMD shit, in which case have at it I guess, but don't conflate the importance of pokemon in a spinoff where all of humanity is gone (the containment series for the dogfuckers, essentially) to the mainline universe, where they're glorified magic dogs.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53216817
It takes place near a canon region but not in one. There's little ties, like how a character has ties to a group from that region, but I want to keep them separate vistas. It's always taken me out of fanfiction when it leans too heavily on canon stuff or characters, because you know that's not what the "real" version of that stuff would be like. I tried to keep to the naming conventions of that region though.

>>53217040
>>53217085
I do want it to be a Pokemon story since that's the key part of the story; the main character doesn't have a Pokemon and you find out the details of why and how that ties into the conflict throughout. Putting aside that I'm worried about boring my Pokemon readers by not having enough Pokemon, the other thing I'm more worried about from a story standpoint is making it feel like the world is alive around the main character and moving past him in a way he's not really a part of since he has no Pokemon. Reading through my story it sometimes feels a little jarring to me how I can have a straightforward interrogation scene or a fight and then a Pokemon shows up

Sorry I'm sort of spitballing here. I'm trying to figure out what I'm doing and it helps to put it in words.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53217186
I think in most instances you are just overthinking it. You should be featuring pokemon as a whole, likely as setting dressing in the background or making a quick point to your character arc before moving on, but there is nothing stopping you from just writing about humans doing human things in the world. Keep in mind that if you genuinely feel like they aren't prevalent enough in your early plot, that is a change you are going to have to make.

Have pokemon outside. Have pokemon on TV. Have pokemon advertisements. Have other people with pokemon. Describe the character's feelings regarding these things. Things in passing, but things that are there.

In my setting Pokemon like Milcery and especially Alcremie are rare in the wild, with Milcery needing specific conditions to spawn outside of breeding -Ambient fairy energy in an area with some sort of cream like material-

Alcremie evolution in this setting is triggered by Milcery maturing + some kind of material as a catalyst for their evolution, so you can get all kinds of potential results for Alcremie, have it absorb enough mud and it'll look muddy and taste like dirt.
Can even go the edgelord route and absorb enough blood to trigger an Alcremie that looks bloody and has a metalic taste.

I hate how the word 'edge' has put people off creating dark scenarios. There's a difference between oc donutsteel with black and red hair burning down an orphanage just because he felt like it, and an actual grounded scene with dark themes like death, mutilation, etc.

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53243301
What gives Edge its reputation isn't the darkness of the content, but the handling that presumes that there is narrative value simply in the presentation of darkness.

Think of it in terms of the edgy OC memes, where the character sheet is a mash up of "edgy" features, but no actual characterization behind that.

The lousy kind of edgy writing is the kind that keeps portraying edgy events without doing anything with them. The good kind uses it sparingly and immediately converts it into motivation or conflict for the characters to resolve.

You're fine if you're using the character death to start a plot arc. You're not if you're using it to justify having the MC put on black clothing, earrings with skulls, spiked wrist bands, to comb his hair over his eyes, and write haikus about the virtues of nihilism.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53243301
Ultimately the edge factor will depend on your protagonist's mindset. If he's going to be the broody revenging guy who single mindedly hunts down his enemies to avenge a guy the audience only knew for a few paragraphs, you're well on your way to Sonic OC hell.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53243991
Misdreavus, Audino, Dunsparce, Cutiefly, Smeargle, and Riolu are top tiers.

Cuteifly would be on every other team if it/sticky webs aren't banned.

Smeargle is utter cancer since it has access to Spore in a meta with few viable Grass types.

Misdreavus' stats are way too high, it's the fastest Pokemon in the tier except for Abra and Pikachu.

Audino's bulk and movepool second only to Smeargle would make it an immovable wall and irreplaceable utility 'mon. It also has Regenerator. Only thing holding it back is one of the best Pokemon in the tier being Riolu.

Riolu's access to Prankster + Copycat means that it's an absurd revenge killer and anti-lead. Smeargle and Cutiefly setting up webs? So are you next turn. Slap a Chesto on it and you can counter-Spore the Smeargle. 70 base Attack is nothing to scoff at when the only Pokemon with a higher Attack stat is Machop. Farfetchd and Pikachu can put out more DPS with their signature items, but for a Pokemon with such an insane niche already, having the 4th strongest physical attacks in the tier is just the cherry on top.

Dunsparce might also be banworthy. Low tier Pokemon with 2x the BST have trouble breaking through Coil Dunsparce sometimes already. Sure, Riolu could come in and Copycat the Coil, but it just OHKOs your ass right back if it Coils again.
>+2 252 Atk Dunsparce Body Slam vs. +1 0 HP / 0 Def Riolu: 252-297 (114 - 134.3%) -- guaranteed OHKO

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53244612
Going further into detail on Misdreavus since I got cucked on character count:

Misdreavus is an insane SpD wall with absurd speed for the tier. It can easily no-sale Abra and Special Pikachus that outspeed it, and it OHKOs both of them back.
>252+ SpA Life Orb Misdreavus Hex (65 BP) vs. 0 HP / 0 SpD Pikachu: 199-234 (94.3 - 110.9%) -- 68.8% chance to OHKO
>252+ SpA Light Ball Pikachu Thunderbolt vs. 0 HP / 0 SpD Misdreavus: 205-243 (78.5 - 93.1%) -- guaranteed 2HKO

Misdreavus is frailer on the physical side, but the meta lacks great physical threats, none of which are faster than Misdreavus. You'd HAVE TO pack a scarfed physical revenge killer for it. Its Hex set is just too strong since it gets Thunder Wave and Will-o-Wisp to cripple everything in the tier. To counter it you'd need Audino with Heal Bell, but Heal Bell was made an exclusive move to Chansey's line in Gen 9. Dunsparce, the threat that it is, also has trouble with Misdreavus since neither Body Slam nor Earthquake can hit it. It can use Glare since Ghosts haven't been immune to Glare since Gen IV, but Misdreavus can also cripple Dunsparce with Thunder Wave or WoW. If Misdreavus is packing sub, there is nothing Dunsparce can do to break Misdreavus while Misdreavus can whittle away Dunsparce with Burn chip or whatever last coverage move you chose (Draining Kiss, Pain Split, Thunderbolt, Energy Ball, Psyshock, and so on)

So, imo, the tier would be

Misdreavus >= Dunsparce > Riolu >= Smeargle >= Cutiefly > Audino > Pikachu > Gastly > Machop > Snivy > Fletchling > Bunnelby > everything else

There's more evidence of ghosts, aliens, and cryptids than there is of any god, be it the abrahamic one or otherwise.
>Aliens
We exist. It's not a stretch to say that other sapient life exists elsewhere, but we can't find it because of one reason or another (they don't want us to, they're so distant that what we see means they're either already dead or haven't evolved yet that or they can see the dinosaurs and not us yet)
>Cryptids
We discover new species all the time and have found species we thought extinct still alive. Less likely than aliens (especially shit like bigfoot) but still plausible provided you believe they're just undiscovered species and not magical creatures.
>Ghosts
Can't really exist given the lack of souls existing unless they're something else. If they were proven to be actual souls and actually exist however, that means that some sort of afterlife exists but the question then becomes "which one, if any, of the existing ones?" and that becomes an important thing to answer. For all we know they could exist and just be some weird fuckery with the electric signals in our brains and earth's natural magnetic field (the most likely explanation should they be proven real), basically imprinting out dying thoughts on our environment or something.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For the sake of this thread, will be considered a "victory road", not simply the location named this way, but any area you have to cross before getting to the league.
It's not so much about which one is objectively THE BEST but which ones YOU personally prefer

For me

>1# Jotho's route 27/28+victory's road
The victory road itself is a joke, but the heroic music after discovering you're in KAAANTOOO gave me the impression I was on the road to the world championship or something. Far from the hardest challenge, but the most memorable

>2#Hoenn's victory road
Extremely difficult cave that makes you crawl in the dark. The final battle against a rival you've long forgotten and the peaceful music after you finally cross it. Kino

>3#Sinnoh victory's road
Nearly the same as Hoenn, but Hoenn did it better for me. It's great for having an entirely optional section though

>4#Kanto's victory road
Epic music before and after the cave to build up the tension, and Moltres, of course

>#5Unova's victory road
The only reason it's behind Kanto is because Kanto as a moltres in it, it's a very good victory road in an on itself

>#6 Kalos' victory road
The road itself is more memorable than the league, that's saying something. It's still nothing to write home about

The other games didn't keep me interested long enough to finish them. I'm excited to see your rankings though

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
best to worst
>Unova Route 23 + BW2 Victory Road
Just feels so great to be outside again after fighting Team Plasma in a cold, lifeless crater. Badge gates look amazing as ever
the geography of the Victory Road itself is amazing. Multiple rooms with distinct environnements, new tiles and fairly challenging trainers (though my memory is altered by romhacks). takes full advantage of the fully optional HMs
>Hoenn Victory Road
RSE: Pretty standard cave with fucked up mapping and lots of rooms to get lost in. Final underwhelming battle to make you confident of your capabilities
ORAS: Much more atypical than in the original, trainers take full advantage of the national dex. Final climactic battle to show you growth of other characters
>Johto Route 26/27 + Victory Road
Music is amazing and it is a new area despite being Kanto. Victory Road itself is pretty boring gameplay-wise but it's great thematically. tough battle against Silver at the end
>Kanto Route 23 + Victory Road
Absolutely love how you can access Route 23 before having all eight badges. it is a location that very early, drives you to push forward on the badge quest. Victory Road itself is fine with a new mechanic
>Unova Route 10 + BW Victory Road
Love the music building up with the badge gates, but it doesn't have quite as much effect as Kanto's since you can only access to area much later.
Victory Road itself is really grandiose with the zoom-out on the massive mountain that you can slide off at any moment, makes you feel like you're skillfully walking on a tight line
>Alola Ultra Victory Road
While much better structured than SM's, still a lack of a challenge. optional legendary being served on a silver plate is something I dislike immensely
>Sinnoh Victory Road
Thoroughly uninspired and boring. Music isn't even good. Bike puzzles are good but I don't like the dungeon as a whole. Feel like the Marley sidequest shouldn't be locked to postgame

Okay then, let's go over them all.
>Kanto
Boring cave with shitty Strength gimmick
>Johto
Lol
>Hoenn
Boring cave
>Sinnoh
Boring cave
>Unova
Boring cave that wastes 20 minutes before you even step foot in it on a shitty KANTOOO throwback
>Kalos
Boring cave
>Alola
Lol
>Galar
Lol
>Paldea
Lmao, but replaces it with something far better
Not even fangames get Victory Roads right, looking at Clover, Reborn, or Unbound. They're all shit. Victory Road should ideally be some complex dungeon that uses gimmicks throughout your adventure to serve as a final test, maybe have callbacks to earlier areas or have diverse environments to make it clear this is the last hurdle you have to overcome before the ultimate trainers in the region. But they're all just shitty caves with the same Golbats and """"Ace Trainers""" rolling around with 2 Pokemon you oneshot, except for the ones that don't even make that effort like Galar.
If they're going to go the boring and simple route they could at least spice up the last level or shake up the formula a bit, like with Area Zero

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>BW2
This one had a nice range of sub-biomes, and I love how it's attached to the ruins of N's Castle.

>XY
Going up and around the mountain to reach the Kalos League made this one the most stunning, visually. It had a few notable gimmicks too, like Pokemon attacking you from the sky or from the ceiling of caves.

>USUM
Nothing special, but a nice upgrade from the original SM. Mt. Lanikila music is great. Finding Necrozma in a crater was cool.

>Johto
I like how its an empty version of the Victory Road from the first game, just you and Silver. The routes leading up to this point were the real Victor Road.

The rest I'm indifferent.

decided to backtrack and post story from then anyways
-
It'd been about a week since Hannah's solitary triumph at Elesa's gym. By now, the group were ready to move on from Nimbasa, and leave it and Tex behind.

They crossed the Dritfveil bridge, exchanging pleasantries and trying to make their circumstances slightly less awkward, eventually arriving where they'd initially intended to end up...
...Driftveil.

The city was... a little less spectacular than Pillow had imagined. Mostly a collection of warehouses and large one-story homes. The most notable building to its name was the church on a hill in the north, and maybe the mines even further north than that.

Regardless of its plain qualities, Pillow was... relieved. Relieved to be here. She'd accomplished something, and this city was quaint- much unlike the hustle and bustle of the last few they'd visited. The change was quite refreshing, and such a sentiment was soon echoed by Sylvia.

The group promptly split, just for a moment. Tea and Hairdo wanted to find where the gym was, while Sylvia and Pillow decided to go and hang out near the Cold Storage in the north. Hannah tagged along for the company, though she didn't talk much.

When the girls got there, however, they were given plenty to talk about.
That Beheeyem pair and their Braviary boss could be spotted once again, up on a podium and seemingly trying to rile up the Pokemon living there- spouting untruths about how Pokemon had been treated as second-class citizens, and citing the contempt the workers of the Storage had for the wilds living there. The tactic seemed to be working, as the small crowd of mon that'd gathered around the mysterious trio seemed rather loud and excited.

So excited, in fact, that a Herdier in the crowd quickly took notice of the newcomers I've been documenting and rushed to hold up Hannah specifically as an example.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53204714
"Look, look!" the Herdier exclaimed, holding up a claw to the Bolt badge shining on Hannah's shoulder. "You're right, Mr Ghetsis sir! This Boldore even has a badge bolted right into her shoulder!"
An ineffectual paw at the accessory yielded little movement, prompting the dog to continue with a slightly more disgusted expression. "I bet her trainer forced her to fight until she was exhausted, and made the badge this way so that he could show off!"

This stranger was, of course, smacked away by Hannah soon after. The only reason she hadn't done so sooner was purely due to how tired she was after Nimbasa. In that respect, the Herdier had a point. Hannah could really use some time to rest after that.

The Braviary called back, though, a grin forming on his beak as the entire crowd turned to the new trio. He quickly affirmed the Herdier's train of thought, giving a sharp nod toward the Herdier and continuing to make an example of Hannah. "Truly despicable behavior. But it's to be expected from humankind, now isn't it?"

Pillow and Sylvia just watched on in exasperation as the crowd began to slowly cut them off from her. It didn't seem an intentional effort- it was too scattershot for that- but it did make things much harder for the two mon who actually KNEW Hannah, and wanted to prevent her identity from being twisted into one of victimhood. Eventually, the crowding got so bad that Sylvia attempted to Slash her way through, only to be instantly bombarded by a crowd of already-riled-up attendees.
Pillow quickly came to her aid, as did Hannah, though the crowd proved hard to beat back. Hannah especially nearly drowned in the swarm, only making her way out of it by creating an entire cage of rocks around her with her Rock Slide attack.

She introduced herself as Pansy- a well-liked member of the Cold Storage wilds who'd migrated there from Route 6- before immediately taking responsibility and offering to help the group with any expenses they might accrue as result of the mob.
Thankfully, those totalled to a three-digit number, but the Deerling found herself wanting to stick with the group regardless. So she took them on a tour of the city once the payment was well and done, too. Just for good measure.

From there, the girls reunited with the boys and told of all that'd happened. Their goal returned to beating the gym, though where to go from there... not many of them were sure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
After their clean victory against Clay, the future of Pillow's team was uncertain.

Everyone was looking to her for input. She was the one who'd wanted to come to Driftveil in the first place, and now she wasn't sure if she'd be leading the team out of it.

Back at Clay's, Tea had evolved. Maybe this was where his conquest for strength would end? And Pillow- she'd received a Moon stone from the miner. It hadn't been used yet, but... it was only a matter of time until that was no longer true.
Nervous, the Munna simply looked to her accomplices.

Hairdo seemed ambivalent to the whole affair, looking moreso in Tea's direction than Pillow's. Hannah just looked *tired,* more in need of a rest than anyone else. She smiled towards Pillow as they locked eyes for just a moment, though it was clearly half-hearted. Sylvia and Tea were talking amongst themselves, both very enthusiastic- Sylvia at Tea's evolution, and Tea at Sylvia's absolute annihilation of Clay's team.

Did they really need her here?
Pillow opened her mouth to suggest something, only for Tea to shout over her. "Come on, let's go to Mistralton! There's no way anything else'll be able to stop me, and I want a challenge!"
Both concrete pillars were raised in triumph as the Conkeldurr exclaimed as much, with Sylvia giggling along with her dodging of them.

Their minds were made up, then.
Pillow huffed, before floating off towards Route 6 with little more than a nod. It took some time until she heard the rest of them follow.

Eventually, the five-man band made it to... a cave? Right, they'd have to go through Chargestone.
Hairdo led the way, making sure the rest were following as he stepped right in. The static atmosphere immediately made his feelers twitch, though he ignored the discomfort in favor of figuring out where exactly they were going. Thankfully, finding that out didn't take too long...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53208723
Floor after floor passed the parade by. Hannah seemed to grow weary with each passing one, increasingly slowing and sometimes wincing for no clear reason at all. All the while, they saw shadows of several different mon, all indistinguishable. The only unifying factor amongst them all was a badge branded with a familiar P.

By the time they'd made it to the deepest parts of the cavern, something was clearly wrong. Aside from Hannah now cringing like she'd suffered some kind of severe injury, Pillow could immediately make out multiple Plasma Grunts lining the halls. All human- all looked semi-lucid, unlike the rabid attackers from before. Looked...

Hannah eventually keeled over, prompting the entire hall to stare daggers in the group's direction. That look only meant one thing- *fight.*
Within seconds, grunts were assailing them on all sides. Sometimes they were accompanied by far more competent Pokémon, sometimes they simply lunged at the group as if they were Pokémon themselves. Fight after fight, battle after battle- the team began to grow weary. But eventually, the circle surrounding Hannah was engulfed in a brilliant red glow-
-and were soon met with the sight of a Gigalith, taking no time at all to join in the fight.

While the entire debacle went down, there was a moment- just a moment- that'd engulfed Pillow and shaken her once more.
Just as the light flashed, she was met with the immediate face of Snorkel, once more. Very clearly in front of her, staring right into her, wearing Plasma gear.

Her immediate reaction was rather obvious. She was going crazy, right? She was going crazy. There was no way he was standing right there.
And yet, once the scarlet glow of her compatriot's evolution dissipated, Snorkel remained. Like a Deerling in the headlights.

And then he was gone, running down the hall like they were never supposed to see him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53208772
It was only after everyone had long left the cave that Pillow managed to come to her senses.

Tea Burr had ended up restraining her, tired of her attempts to chase after something the Conkeldurr was sure wasn't even there.
Only Sylvia had objected to the idea, and was quickly deterred after seeing just how frantic the Munna had gotten.

That same Munna now lay on a cushion, staring at the ceiling of the Mistralton City Pokemon Center, facing four mon with clear disappointment in their faces.
Behind them stood Skyla, gym leader.
She promptly explained what'd happened since- Pillow had freaked out, only to pass out, and be brought to the center while sometimes kicking in what she could only assume was her sleep.

Pillow sat up instantly, trying to explain the situation in the same frantic tone she usually used. Her team expressed an equally-disapproving response, with Hannah not even looking her in the eyes.
The Munna begged for her to be believed just one more time, only for Skyla to intervene and shake her head. She explained that if this Patrat really was supposed to be dead, then Pillow was likely just having hallucinations. But, she continued, there was a certain place on Route 7 that could help settle this once and for all.

Celestial Tower... that was their next destination.

>>53208815
The trek to Celestial Tower was a quiet one. Mostly filled with meaningless small talk and cutesy chatter. By now, the team was beginning to realize that there was little reason for them to have a goal- just being together was fun enough for them to go along with it. Though, plenty still found it meaningful to have something to aim for...

...suddenly, Sylvia began to notice a sixth pair of footsteps accompanying theirs. She turned left to see a quiet Audino walking a short distance away from them, seemingly tracing their trail. She paid no mind to him for a little while, but by the time the Tower was in view she began getting suspicious, so the Leavanny stopped a moment and introduced herself to the stranger.

The stranger introduced himself back, naming himself as Potpourri, and claiming to be headed towards Celestial Tower for a relative.
Pillow overheard and floated over, but didn't say anything at first. Nor did Sylvia; she just nodded and gave her apologies, before continuing towards the tower with the rest of the group.

And once they arrived, the long climb upwards began.
There wasn't much trouble, for the most part, save for the soul-sucking candles melted atop many of the graves. Occasionally someone would claim to see an alien, or a trainer near the graves would attack.
Such minor issues eventually began to pile up over time, and around halfway through the tower the team began to tire.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53209835
Once exhaustion began to seep into the group's mood, Potpourri finally spoke up. He offered herbal remedies to the group, and general medical care while they were there. For free.

The team didn't hesitate, and Potpourri got to helping them. He hummed a little tune as he applied tonics and pastes and bandages and berries. He made small talk, gave encouragement, and generally helped everyone press on- before once again fading into the background, with little more than a happy smile on his face.

The quintet was too busy making it to the top to question things. So much so that, when they got there, Pillow was somewhat surprised when Potpourri stepped forward and expressed his intent to ring the bell. Initially, the Munna floated forward to ring the bell herself, but... hesitated.

Potpourri took that as a resignation, and he stepped forward to ring it himself.
Once he did, another Audino came forward- about his height, but noticeably more torn. The two conversed for a time, with Potpourri acting as if the occurrence was completely normal throughout, before stepping back and motioning for Pillow to take the reins.

And so, the Munna floated forward and rang the bell...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53209878
...ring, ring...

The sound echoed throughout the area, and with each ding came forth another spirit. Goggles, Snorkel, Mittens, Tex- each one came forward, all setting their sights on Pillow as the Munna realized just how many other mon she'd seen pass on.

Upon seeing Tex, however, Hannah was the first to come forward, instantly going over to the Sandile to profusely apologize and ask useless questions about his mood or how he was feeling. Tea noticed Mittens and came over to apologize for not listening to the Pansear back in Pinwheel.

Pillow just... stared.
He was really dead, wasn't he?
She didn't know what this meant. Whether she really had lost her mind, or whether the bell was faulty, or... what.
But that didn't matter. In the moment, Snorkel was right there, waiting for her to say something.
And so she did.

Nearly an hour passed before the spirits began to fade. Sylvia and Potpourri hung back while the rest of the team conversed with them- Hairdo eventually coming to join them and talk with both Mittens and Tex. It wasn't easy on any of them- Tea was bawling, Hairdo couldn't help but shed a tear, and even Hannah- though she tried to hide it- wept for Tex.

Pillow...
Pillow seemed fine, at first. Once Snorkel slipped away from her, there was no reaction. Neutrality. Ambivalence.

Before she began to break down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53209942
Nobody came to her, at first. They weren't sure whether comforting someone who'd gotten them in so much trouble was a good idea, and Hairdo especially had already written her off as having lost her mind a long time ago.

Then Sylvia came over to give her a hug.
Hannah gave her a slight nudge.
Tea came over just to finalize it.

Pillow was almost in disbelief. Both of the hug and of Snorkel. She knew he was gone, and there he was- among the dead. But...
...
...no, that didn't matter.

The Munna simply accepted the hug, remaining in the group's embrace until her tears finally left her.
It was time to move on, and she'd accepted that.

The group eventually began making its way down the stairs. Pillow floated after them, with Potpourri lingering just a little longer to give the bell another look.
As the Munna descended, she figured out the perfect way to leave her more neurotic self behind for good-

-and left Celestial Tower as a Musharna.
From there on out, only two things mattered. That her team was safe, and that the next gym was defeated.
Snorkel could wait.

I am very glad that I can finally put this arc to rest because writing unlikeable characters hurts when they're also delusional and unjustified
Pillow was a shithead whom I gave too much attention, and I am more than happy to move on lmfao
hopefully she wasn't as irritating to read as she was to write lol

Just got done with inclement emerald, that game as a massive difficulty curve throughout the whole midgame that then proceeds to nosedive down to baby tier once you have access to items/moves/mons post mossdeep.
Double weather is fairly busted though, and the AI can be really dumb sometimes. I think having so many coverage moves on the boss battles fucks the AI over more than it helps.
Most battles started like this
>Lead gigalith sand stream, AI goes for ground move/fighting move/water move/maybe a grass move
>switch to gyarados, intimidate and not very effective/immunity. AI goes for its coverage electric/rock move
>switch to excadrill
>life orb sand rush EQ/Rock Slide/Iron Head/Aerial Ace kills everything.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53210835
The E4 itself was pretty cut and dry, here are the individual kill counts:
Slate - 4
Cobalt - 3
Navy - 2
Bubblegum - 1 (with an assist)
Scarlet - 8 (queen shit)
Periwinkle - 2

Now onto the main event...
Cobalt sang his Perish Song to Gyarados, the two traded blows then we switched in Periwinkle & Aerodactyl. I predicted T!Fang and sent in Slate to a Rock Slide. Now this is where the fun begins. Slate mows down Aero with 2 Rollouts and the injured Gyara with a 3rd. Out comes the first Drago who misses a Dragon Rush and dies to the 4th. Slate then tanks a Rush from the second Drago and steamrolls him with the 5th.

Things are looking amazing, the battle is now 6v2. Lance sends out his ace Drago and I switch in Periwinkle, who is crushed immediately with an Outrage. Scarlet goes in to tank the Outrages and land some Wing Attacks. I bait a Fire Blast and switch into Cobalt, but before my precious froggy can freeze this mf, Drago outspeeds and brutally murders Cobalt w/ Outrage. Scarlet flies back in to repeat the same strat from before. Her health is now yellow and Bubblegum comes in to tank a Fire Blast before Body Slamming Drago. The tyrant is finally dead!

All that's left is Charizard, who spams Air Slash while I counter w/ Milk Drinks and Body Slams when possible. At this point Lance still has all but 1 of his Full Restores, so he heals whenever BG gets Zard down to yellow. BG nerfs him w/ Captivate and paralyzes again, so Zard switches to phys attacks and burns BG w/ Fire Fang, making it harder to wittle his health down. Predicting Dragon Claw, Navy comes out and hits hard w/ Night Slash, then somehow TANKS AN AIR SLASH (thank god for Captivate). Knowing Navy, Scarlet & BG are too weak to finish off Zard, I risk it all on Slate, who eats a Fire Fang and mauls Zard w/ a final Rollout.

Never would I have thought a Donphan would slaughter Lance's almost entire team w/ Rollout. Now to lay two dear friends to rest and prepare for a new journey to Kanto.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
After Celestial Tower, it was only a matter of time until another tragedy struck the team.

Unfortunately for them, it came in a terrifying one-two punch.
As they entered Twist Mountain, rumbles could be heard throughout. The team elected to ignore such foreboding, knowing how the mountain was home to many ground-and-rock types, but such a decision would not do them well...

About halfway through their trek, a landslide came after the quintet. They were lucky enough to have a light at the end of the tunnel they were going through.
The very narrow tunnel they were going through.
As the tsunami of earth began chasing the team, Hairdo thought it wise to let the slower mon go first so they wouldn't be crushed. The Unfezant stopped only to ram Tea Burr as hard as he can, making sure he fit through the doorframe and got to the other side, only for his next move to be doing the same to Pillow as she lagged behind.

Unfortunately, during this affair, Hairdo had forgotten to move himself.

He was only alerted to this fact when Sylvia bumped directly into him, shrieking. Turning to see the source of the noise, all Hairdo saw was a tower of dirt and rocks coming down upon both of them.
The last thing he saw was Sylvia vanishing into the debris, as he soon followed suit.


It took Pillow and Hannah nearly half an hour to process what had happened.
Pillow had been staring daggers into the mess of earth that was now spilling out the passageway. Hannah wasn't far behind. Tea Burr was too busy hugging them both to look.
Any day now. Any day, they'd come out. Hairdo would emerge from the pile, holding up Sylvia like a princess, proclaiming their victory.

Any day now...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The rest of the trek through Twist Mountain was silent. Even arriving in Icirrus City and hearing joyous dance music from a travelling troupe couldn't lift the trio's spirits. On a whim, Pillow simply floated over to a Corviknight taxi and prompted the rest of the team to follow her.

The next few weeks were spent resting. The team went back to Nimbasa for some lighthearted entertainment, picking up a Ferroseed along the way who immediately hit it off with Hannah and insisted on staying with them.

From there, they went to Nuvema for a quiet beach vacation far from Undella's loud tourists. While there, Pillow was approached by a kindly Frillish, seemingly having taken an interest in the team, who offered to join after explaining that her school of Frillish had left her behind a few days ago and she had yet to find them- but knew travelling with this group would be a great learning opportunity.
Little hesitation was had in bringing her on board- and so, Dolores accompanied the rest of the crew on their quiet retreat.

It was only after Hannah overheard a pair of Team Plasma Pokémon eagerly discussing the Dragon they were about to awaken in Icirrus that the team felt it pertinent to return to the city and pursue Dragonspiral Tower...
